importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The crash occurred in September 2025, marking the timeline of the fatal event and the subsequent investigation into the structural and operational failures.

keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon broke and caused a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured several others.
The cable failed to meet the certification standards required by CARRIS, the operator of the funicular.
The cable also failed to meet the operator’s internal specifications, indicating a breach in safety protocols.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant despite not being properly executed.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Eyewitnesses described the descent as chaotic and uncontrolled, with one man named Bruno describing it as 'a toy being thrown' across the street.
The preliminary report is not conclusive, and a final report is expected to be released in 2026.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, resulted in at least 16 deaths and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped during operation. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet both certification standards set by the operator CARRIS and internal specifications. Additionally, maintenance records show falsified entries, with tasks marked as completed even when not performed. Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the descent as chaotic and uncontrolled. While the interim report identifies serious safety failures, it is noted to be preliminary, and a final report is expected in 2026.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
